legal_source: Ill. Admin. Code tit. 68, § 1410.200 - Standards of Practice

key_definitions.inspect: To visually examine readily accessible systems and components using normal operating controls and opening readily accessible panels
key_definitions.readily_accessible: Available for visual inspection WITHOUT moving personal property, dismantling, destructive measures, or risk to persons or property
key_definitions.readily_operable_access_panel: A panel provided for homeowner inspection and maintenance that is within normal reach, can be removed by one person, and is not sealed in place
key_definitions.representative_number: One component per room for multiple similar interior components (windows, doors, outlets); one component on each side for exterior components
key_definitions.dismantle: To take apart or remove any component that would not be taken apart by a homeowner in normal routine maintenance

required_descriptions: Methods used to inspect under-floor crawl space or basement area
Methods used to inspect floors, walls, ceilings, framing, roof
required_reports: Visible signs of water and moisture penetration into building
Signs of condensation on building components
Infestation that significantly impacts structure or integrity of home
customer_question_examples: Why didn't you crawl under the house?
Is the foundation safe?
Why didn't you give a structural engineer report?

responses.crawl_space_not_accessible: Per Illinois law, inspectors only inspect readily accessible crawl spaces. If entry is unsafe, blocked, or creates risk to the inspector, it is not required. Your inspector disclosed this in the report.
responses.foundation_not_unsafe: Home inspection reports visible conditions but does not make engineering judgments about safety. For structural safety evaluation, hire a licensed structural engineer.
responses.foundation_settling_normal: Visible foundation conditions are reported. Whether settling is concerning requires professional engineering evaluation beyond home inspection scope.

required_inspections: Attached decks, balconies, stoops, steps, porches, landings, and railings
Eaves, soffits, fascia or other exposed trim (if readily accessible from ground level)
Vegetation, grading, surface drainage, retaining walls on property
Walkways, patios, driveways leading to dwelling entrances
required_reports: If any exterior component is likely to adversely affect the building
customer_question_examples: Why didn't you inspect the roof edge?
Why didn't you check the gutters?
Why didn't you go on the deck?

responses.deck_safety: Deck inspection is required. However, if deck is unsafe or creates risk to inspector, steps may be limited and documented in report.
responses.gutter_inspection: Gutters are part of roof drainage system. Visual inspection from ground is required. Cleaning debris or disassembly is not required.

required_reports: Methods used to inspect roof (e.g., from ground, ladder, attic)
customer_question_examples: Why didn't you walk on the roof?
Why didn't you climb on the roof?
How can you inspect the roof without getting on it?

responses.roof_not_walked: Per Illinois law, roof inspection is required. However, walking on the roof is NOT required. Visual inspection from ground level using binoculars, ladder, or from attic satisfies inspection requirement. If roof is brittle, damaged, or unsafe (creating risk to person), walking on it is not appropriate. Your inspector used safe methods to inspect roof condition.
responses.climbing_not_required: Illinois law requires inspection of roof condition. Climbing on roof creates risk to person and is not required. Your inspector reported the inspection method used (ground level inspection) in the report.
responses.height_visibility_safety: Inspectors make professional decisions to avoid safety risks while meeting inspection requirements. Visual inspection from safe distance is valid per Illinois standards.

required_inspections: Interior water supply and distribution systems (fixtures, faucets, piping, drains, waste, vent systems)
Drainage sumps, sump pump and related piping
required_descriptions: Interior water supply and distribution systems in detail
Fuel storage and distribution in detail
Drainage sumps, sump pump and related piping in detail
required_reports: Location of main water and main shut-off valves
customer_question_examples: Why didn't you test water quality?
Why didn't you check water pressure?
Did you test the water for contamination?

responses.water_quality: Water quality testing is NOT part of home inspection per Illinois standards. Inspection includes visual examination of supply and distribution systems. For water quality testing, hire a laboratory or environmental specialist.
responses.water_pressure: Water pressure testing is beyond home inspection scope. Inspection includes visual examination of components and operation of normal controls. For detailed plumbing evaluation, hire a licensed plumber.
responses.well_water: If property is on well water, water quality testing is recommended but not required by inspection standards. Customer should contact local health department about testing requirements.

required_inspections: Service entrance conductors, cables, and raceways
INTERIOR COMPONENTS OF SERVICE PANELS AND SUBPANELS
Representative number of installed lighting fixtures, switches, and receptacles
required_descriptions: Amperage and voltage rating of service
Location of main disconnects and subpanels
required_reports: Presence of solid conductor aluminum branch circuit wiring
Non-compliance with Carbon Monoxide Alarm Detector Act (430 ILCS 135)
Non-compliance with Smoke Detector Act (425 ILCS 60)
customer_question_examples: Why didn't you open the electrical panel?
Why didn't you open the breaker panel?
Shouldn't you have opened the main panel to check it?
Did you test all the outlets?

responses.panel_opening_required: Per Illinois law (Ill. Admin. Code tit. 68, § 1410.200(k)), inspectors are REQUIRED to inspect interior components of service panels and subpanels. Your inspector opened the panel and inspected all required components. This is a legal requirement, not optional.
responses.panel_interior_inspection: Illinois law specifically requires inspection of interior components of electrical panels and subpanels. Your inspector followed the law and professional standards by opening the panel and documenting the service size, wiring, breakers, and grounding.
responses.representative_outlets: Illinois law requires inspection of a representative number of outlets (not all). Your inspector tested outlets throughout the house per standard practice.
responses.gfci_testing: Ground fault circuit interrupters are required to be inspected per Illinois law. These were tested during the inspection.

required_inspections: Visible vent systems, flues, and chimneys
customer_question_examples: Why didn't you test the heating efficiency?
How can you say the furnace is working if you didn't test it thoroughly?
Should I get a specialist to evaluate heating?

responses.heating_efficiency: Home inspection includes operation of heating system using normal controls. Efficiency testing and detailed performance evaluation are beyond home inspection scope. For efficiency audit, hire a licensed HVAC technician.
responses.heating_operation: Inspector tested heating system operation with normal controls per Illinois requirement. Further evaluation of efficiency or repairs requires HVAC specialist.
responses.furnace_age: Inspector documented furnace type and condition. For detailed evaluation or recommendations about replacement or repair, consult licensed HVAC contractor.

required_inspections: Permanently installed central and through-wall cooling equipment
customer_question_examples: Why didn't you test the air conditioning thoroughly?
Did you test cooling efficiency?
Should I get the AC serviced?

responses.ac_efficiency: Air conditioning system was tested for operation per Illinois requirement. Efficiency testing and performance evaluation are beyond home inspection scope. For AC service or efficiency testing, hire licensed HVAC contractor.
responses.ac_operation: Inspector tested AC operation using normal controls. If system is shut down, not functioning, or needs service, hire licensed HVAC technician.
responses.ac_capacity: Cooling system inspection includes operation and condition assessment. For capacity evaluation or upgrade recommendations, consult HVAC specialist.

required_reports: Visible signs of water and moisture penetration into building
Signs of condensation on building components
customer_question_examples: Why didn't you test every window?
Did you check all the doors?
Why didn't you operate the garage door multiple times?

responses.representative_number: Inspector tested a representative number of similar components (windows, doors, outlets) per Illinois standards. Not every individual item requires separate testing.
responses.interior_condition: Interior inspection documents condition of visible components. Cosmetic or minor functional issues may not be reported if they don't significantly affect safety or operation.

required_inspections: Insulation and vapor retarders in unfinished spaces
Ventilation of attics and foundation areas
Mechanical ventilation systems (attics, kitchens, bathrooms, laundry)
required_descriptions: Insulation and vapor retarders in unfinished spaces
Absence of insulation in unfinished spaces at conditioned surfaces
customer_question_examples: Why didn't you measure insulation thickness?
Did you check if insulation is adequate?
Why is the attic not better insulated?

responses.insulation_adequacy: Inspector documents insulation presence and general condition. Determining adequacy for specific climate or energy efficiency requires energy audit beyond home inspection scope.
responses.insulation_measurement: Insulation inspection is visual. Detailed thickness measurement is beyond home inspection scope. For energy efficiency recommendations, hire energy auditor.

required_descriptions: Fireplaces, solid fuel burning appliances, and chimneys description
required_reports: Significant damage or deterioration that is visible
customer_question_examples: Is the chimney safe to use?
Should the fireplace be cleaned?
Does the chimney work?

responses.chimney_safety: Inspector documents visible chimney condition. For detailed chimney evaluation, cleaning, or safety certification, hire licensed chimney sweep or chimney specialist.
responses.fireplace_use: Inspector documents fireplace condition and notes any visible damage. For safe operation, obtain chimney cleaning and inspection from licensed chimney professional.
responses.fireplace_operation: Fireplace operation was assessed visually. For detailed evaluation of draft, functionality, or safety, hire chimney specialist or fireplace professional.

inspector_not_required_to: Determine condition of any component or system that is NOT readily accessible
Determine service life expectancy of any component or system
Determine cause for need of replacement of any system or component
Operate any system that is shut down or does not turn on with normal operating controls
Enter or access any area that may be unsafe or not readily accessible
Offer warranties, guarantees, or insurance policies of any kind

general_guidelines.inspection_scope: Home inspection is a visual examination of readily accessible systems and components using normal operating controls and opening readily accessible panels
what_not_included: Pest inspection (beyond signs visible to naked eye)

when_to_hire_specialists.structural_engineer: For structural safety evaluation or engineering questions
when_to_hire_specialists.licensed_electrician: For detailed electrical service, upgrades, repairs, panel interior work
when_to_hire_specialists.licensed_plumber: For detailed plumbing evaluation, pressure testing, repairs
when_to_hire_specialists.hvac_contractor: For heating/cooling efficiency, repairs, service, replacement
when_to_hire_specialists.chimney_specialist: For chimney cleaning, detailed evaluation, safety certification
when_to_hire_specialists.environmental_specialist: For mold testing, radon testing, environmental hazards
when_to_hire_specialists.pest_specialist: For detailed pest inspection and identification
when_to_hire_specialists.energy_auditor: For insulation adequacy and energy efficiency evaluation

disclaimer: This information is based on Illinois Home Inspection Standards (Ill. Admin. Code tit. 68, § 1410.200, amended 2/2/2024). This is general information for educational purposes and does not constitute legal advice. For specific compliance questions or legal interpretation, consult an attorney. Home inspectors follow these standards as minimum requirements; individual inspectors may exceed these standards.
